titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the John Z. Bowers papers FA1415

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-10-23 01:14:50 -0400.

physdesc.extent: 37 letter-size boxes, 6 legal-size boxes, 1 half-letter-size box, 1 half-legal-size box, and 4 record carton storage boxes

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is generally arranged as received.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Zimmerman Bowers was born on August 27, 1913 in Catonsville, Maryland. After graduating with his B.S. and M.D. from Gettysburg College and the University of Maryland, respectively, he served in the Naval Medical Corps during World War II. In 1945, before his discharge, Bowers spent six months at Harvard University training in pathology with Dr. Shields Warren, a noted pathologist and specialist in radiobiology.

In 1949, Bowers went to Japan to monitor the long-term biological effects of atomic radiation on the survivors of the attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. This experience, and his later affiliation with the Radioactive Isotope Laboratory in Baltimore and the Crocker Radiation Laboratory of the University of California, Berkeley, led to his appointment in 1981 to the Advisory Committee to the Radiation Effects Research Foundation. He wrote a history of the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission and the Radiation Effects Research Foundation (previously the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission).

Bowers' long-standing interest in Asia and Asian medicine led him to be awarded a China Medical Board fellowship to study medical education in Japan. Over the course of his life, he researched and wrote on medicine in Japan and China, of transitions and tensions between traditional and Western medicine, and medical education.

In 1965, Bowers became President of the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, which worked to advance education in the health sciences. Bowers organized and presided over several international conferences on medical care and education during his tenure at the Macy Foundation, which concluded with his retirement in 1980.

After his retirement, Bowers maintained his affiliation with the Rockefeller Foundation, which had begun in 1964, and served as a consultant. In 1983, he published The Health of Mankind, a history of the Foundation's health and natural science programs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The John Z. Bowers Papers were donated to the Rockefeller Archive Center by John Z. Bowers and later his wife, Akiko Bowers.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The John Z. Bowers Papers were processed by Bethany J. Antos, completed in October 2018.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Medical Center Archives of New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell was donated in 2008 (see the John Z. Bowers Papers, Accession 2008:069).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The John Z. Bowers Papers document the research and writings of Bowers, a physician, educator, and expert on medicine and medical education, particularly in Japan and China. The papers include extensive research and reference materials that Bowers collected as he authored several books. These materials include articles, reprints, and translations, as well as Bowers' own notes and manuscripts.

While Bowers collected much of this information in his later years (1960s-1980s), some of the materials cover much earlier time periods, and a certain amount of the material is in other languages, including Japanese, Chinese, Portuguese, and Spanish.

Of particular interest is a small set of material gifted to Bowers by Dr. Shields Warren, including photographs of Nagasaki in 1947 and observations made during tests of the atomic and hydrogen bombs at Eniwetok/Enewetak in 1948.
Bowers also served as President of the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, and a portion of the collection includes published books which were the result of Macy-sponsored conferences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains research and reference materials related to Bowers' book on The Rise of Western Medicine in Japan. Files include reprints, articles, notes, and translations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains research and reference materials related to several of Bowers' writing projects, including the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission History, Medicine in Japan, and others. Files include reprints, articles, notes, translations, and materials gifted by Dr. Shields Warren. The series also contains publications produced under the auspices of the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation during Bowers' tenure as president. Finally, there is a small subset of personal materials (photographs, a memorial album compiled by Akiko Bowers, etc.).
